Question_1.Context: Incorporating lignin into cellulose nanofibers can affect their biodegradation rate due to lignin's inherent properties.
Question_1.Question: What role does lignin play when incorporated into cellulose nanofibers?
Question_1.B: It acts as an antimicrobial and crosslinking agent to control the biodegradation rate.
Question_1.C: It has no effect on the biodegradation rate.
Question_1.D: It solely acts as a nutrient for soil microbes.
Question_1.Source: We incorporated lignin into CNFs as an antimicrobial and crosslinking agent to control the biodegradation rate.

Question_2.Context: Lignocellulose nanofibers can be characterized by various analytical techniques to confirm the presence of specific functional groups.
Question_2.Question: Which analytical technique can confirm the reaction of succinic acid with lignocellulose in the synthesis of lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_2.Source: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed on the untreated TMP fibers and each of the LCNFs with varying lignin concentrations to confirm the reaction of succinic acid with lignocellulose.

Question_3.Context: Deep eutectic solvents are used in the processing of biomass due to their ability to disrupt the structure efficiently.
Question_3.Question: What is the role of deep eutectic solvents in the processing of lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_3.A: They act as a catalyst for the reaction.
Question_3.B: They increase the thermal stability of the fibers.
Question_3.C: They disrupt the structure of biomass for efficient mechanical processing.
Question_3.D: They decrease the surface area of the fibers.
Question_3.Source: Deep eutectic solvents can be made from organic, non-toxic, and low cost constituents and are effective at disrupting the structure of biomass for efficient mechanical processing.

Question_4.Context: The presence of lignin in cellulose nanofibers can influence the rate at which they degrade when applied to soil.
Question_4.Question: How does the presence of lignin in cellulose nanofibers affect their degradation in soil?
Question_4.A: Lignin presence increases the water solubility of the fibers, leading to faster degradation.
Question_4.B: Lignin has no impact on the degradation rate of the fibers in soil.
Question_4.C: Higher lignin content in the fibers leads to a slower degradation rate in soil.
Question_4.D: Lignin accelerates the microbial digestion of the fibers, increasing degradation.
Question_4.Source: Modifying the lignin content of the fibers successfully modulated the biodegradation rate in soil.

Question_5.Context: Lignin's interaction with enzymes can affect the enzymatic degradation of carbohydrates.
Question_5.Question: What is one way lignin interacts with enzymes to affect the degradation of carbohydrates?
Question_5.A: Lignin increases the activity of carbohydrate-degrading enzymes.
Question_5.B: Lignin forms unproductive binding regions with enzymes, reducing enzyme activity.
Question_5.C: Lignin acts as a catalyst for carbohydrate degradation.
Question_5.D: Lignin has no interaction with enzymes.
Question_5.Source: Lignin forms unproductive binding regions with enzymes and carbohydrates through both hydrophobic and hydroxyl-mediated electrostatic interactions, reducing enzyme activity.

Question_6.Context: The chemical composition of lignocellulose nanofibers can be determined using specific protocols.
Question_6.Question: Which protocol is used to analyze the chemical composition of lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_6.Source: The chemical composition of the bleached pulps was analyzed using the NREL compositional analysis protocols.

Question_7.Context: Carboxylate functionalization of lignocellulose nanofibers can impart specific properties to the fibers.
Question_7.Question: What property can carboxylate functionalization provide to lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_7.Source: Carboxylate functionalization can also provide properties such as electrostatic stabilization in water to produce hydrogels.

Question_8.Context: The synthesis of lignocellulose nanofibers can involve the use of a deep eutectic solvent consisting of specific components.
Question_8.Question: Which components are used to form the deep eutectic solvent in the synthesis of lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_8.Source: Nanofibers were produced via mechanochemical ball milling each bleached pulp and the unbleached TMP in a deep eutectic solvent consisting of urea and choline chloride in a molar ratio of 2 mol urea to 1 mol choline chloride.

Question_9.Context: The degree of functionalization of lignocellulose nanofibers can be quantified by measuring specific content.
Question_9.Question: What content is measured to quantify the degree of succinylation of lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_9.Source: The degree of succinylation was quantified by measuring the carboxylate content of the fibers before and after mechanochemical treatment using conductometric titration.

Question_10.Context: The structural morphology of lignocellulose nanofibers can be visualized using a specific type of microscopy.
Question_10.Question: Which microscopy technique is used to visualize the structural morphology of lignocellulose nanofibers?
Question_10.Source: Scanning electron microscope images of TMP and each of the LCNFs were acquired using a FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 FEGSEM microscope to show the structural morphology before and after mechanochemical treatment.
